Fig. 1 (a) XRD patterns of TSM-0.3, TSM-0.4 and TSM-0.5. (b) FT-IR parretns for TS, MIL-101(Cr), TSM-0.3, TSM-0.4 and TSM-0.5. (c) Ramon spectrum for TS and TSM-0.4. (d) TG and DTG curves for TS and TSM-0.4. Fig 1 Fig. 2 (a) The N2 adsorption−desorption isotherms (77 K) of TS, MIL-101(Cr), TSM-0.3, TSM-0.4 and TSM-0.5. (b) BJH pore size distribution curve of TS, MIL-101(Cr), TSM-0.3, TSM-0.4 and TSM-0.5. Fig 2 Fig. 3 XPS spectra of samples (a) full spectrum, (b) C 1s, (c) Cr 2p, (d) O 1s, (e) S 2p, and (f) Ti 2p. Fig 3 Fig. 4 SEM images of (a, b) MIL-101(Cr) and (c, d) TSM-0.4 (e-i) EDS elemental mappings of TSM-0.4. Fig 4 Fig. 5 (a) The catalytic esterification conversion of LA with EtOH on different catalysts under 100 °C. (b) The conversion of LA to EL on catalyst of TSM-0.4 under different temperature. (c) The recyclability of TSM-0.4 under 120 °C for conversion of LA to EL. (d) The conversions and yields of catalytic esterification of LA with different alcohols. Fig 5 Fig. 6 The reaction mechanism of the proposed TSM catalyst in the esterification of levulinic acid and ethanol. Fig 6 Fig. 7 Infrared spectra of pyridine adsorption for MIL-101(Cr) and TSM-0.4. Fig 7 Fig. 8 Feasibility mechanism for the one-pot cascade reaction of LA to GVL. Fig 8 Fig. 9 (a) The catalytic conversion of LA with isopropanol and yields of different products on different catalysts under 160 °C for 9 h. (b) The catalytic conversion of LA with mixed alcohols of ethanol and isopropanol and yields of different products on TSM-0.4 under 160 °C for 9 h. (c). Yields of products within 9 h in the reaction of LA with mixed alcohols (ethanol/isopropanol = 0.15) in the presence of TSM-0.4 under 160 °C. (d) Yields of products within 9 h in the reaction of LA with isopropanol in the presence of TSM-0.4 under 160 °C. (e) The catalytic conversion of LA with mixed alcohols of ethanol and isopropanol (ethanol/isopropanol = 0.15) and yields of different products on alkila treated MIL-101 (Cr)(AT), porous TiO2 (AT) and TSM-0.4(AT) 160 °C for 9 h. (f) The recyclability of TSM-0.4 under 160 °C for 9 h for LA conversion with mixed alcohols (ethanol/isopropanol = 0.15). Fig 9 Fig. 10 The conversion pathways of ethyl 4-hydroxyvalerate and 4-hydroxyvaleric acid to GVL. Development of heterogeneous catalysts with both Brønsted and Lewis acid properties has proved to be promising and useful because they offer an efficient way to cascade reactions. In this study, we present the synthesis pathway and efficacy evaluation of new composites which combined by sulfonic acid functional group modified TiO2 and MIL-101, analyzing their structure-performance correlation as heterogeneous catalysts in cascade reactions involving esterification, hydrogen transfer, and lactonization. These composites possess an open porous structure (MOF and porous TiO2), as well as active sites including Lewis acid (unsaturated coordination metal), Lewis base (Ti-OH), and Brønsted acid (-SO3H). The role of these active sites and the synergies between them were investigated through the esterification of levulinic acid and the direct synthesis of γ-valerolactone from levulinic acid and furfural under cascade reactions. The composites exhibit a 100% ethyl levulinate (EL) yield at 120°C for 6 hours, with γ-valerolactone yields reaching up to 94.5% (160 °C, 9 h) and 89.5% (160 °C, 16 h) from levulinic acid and furfural, respectively. This synergistic effect of Lewis acid/base and Brønsted acid ensures efficient esterification. The presence of a sulfonic acid group promotes the lactonization reaction, while the Meerwein-Ponndorf-Verley reduction is facilitated by the dual Cr sites located adjacent to each other in the secondary building unit of MIL-101(Cr). Moreover, the double-porous structure of porous TiO2 and MIL-101(Cr) effectively guarantees the efficient mass transfer of reactants and intermediates, leading to enhanced synergistic effects that promote more efficient reaction conversion. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Heterogeneous catalysts Esterification γ-valerolactone Cascade reactions Synergistic effect Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction With the shortage of fossil fuels, biomass as an important renewable resource can replace fossil resources. Therefore, the development and utilization of biomass has received great attention [1]. Levulinic acid is a very important biomass conversion platform, which can be obtained from the conversion of cellulose and benzellulose, and can be further converted into other high value-added products such as levulinate and γ-valerolactone (GVL) [2]. As a compound utilized as an oxygenated supplement in fossil fuels and biodiesel, ethyl levulinate (EL) has demonstrated the ability to lower turbidity point, pour point, and cold filter point, enhance efficiency, facilitate cleaner combustion, and diminish the release of harmful gases. GVL can be considered a sustainable hydrocarbon source for energy and chemicals [3]. The use of GVL as a renewable feedstock has attracted interest given the low toxicity and high stability of this compound. The low vapor pressure of GVL reduces the emission of volatile substances, which allows safe storage. On the other hand, GVL has a high chemical stability, preventing the hydrolysis to the acid form under neutral pH conditions and the formation of peroxides upon heating. These properties make GVL a very attractive compound as a fuel additive to produce cleaner-burning fuels, as a key intermediate in the synthesis of fine chemicals, such as adipic acid, valeric acid [4,5], or 5-nonanone [6], as a solvent, or as a component of biocide formulations [7]. In the traditional biomass transfer process, the most used is the process related to esterification. This requires the use of liquid mineral acids at high temperatures (200∼350°C) and strong mineral acids [8-9]. These processes exhibit inherent drawbacks such as equipment corrosion, challenging recovery processes, and product separation difficulties [10-11]. Therefore, there is a growing interest in the development of multiphase solid acid catalysts that offer enhanced separation ease and regeneration efficiency. In recent years, the rapid development of metal–organic framework (MOF) materials has brought new opportunities for heterogeneous catalysis. MOFs are porous materials made of organic ligands and metal ions/clusters [12-13], which are widely used in catalysis [14-16], adsorption [17], and energy storage [18]. They combine the benefits of organic ligands and metal ions, providing exceptional properties beyond what is expected from their individual components [19-20]. In particular, MIL-101(Cr) with a high surface area can accommodate large molecules in its large cages. Its mesoporosity also facilitates the storage of large molecules in the pores, while retaining its chemical stability [21]. Each secondary building unit (SBU) in MIL-101(Cr) contains two open metal sites, which preferentially absorb biomass molecules [22]. However, MIL-101(Cr) can only provide lewis acid active sites through unsaturated coordination of metal cluster, which cannot play a decisive role in complex biomass conversion systems. In some cascade reactions of biomass conversion, Lewis acids and bases sites, and Brønsted acids sites play an important synergistic role [23]. The incorporation of sulfonic acid (-SO3H) groups or carboxylic acid (-COOH) into MOFs is promising as the uniformly distributed and readily accessible Brønsted acid sites present throughout the MOFs endow the resultant MOFs with exceptionally high efficiency as solid acid catalysts [24-26]. However, the pioneer work of directly assembling Brønsted acid on MOF frame requires expensive organic ligands, long reaction times (more than 7 days) [27-30] or environmentally unfriendly acid post-treatment [31]. The direct introduction of sulfonic acid or carboxylic acid structure can affect the specific surface area of MOF, the pore structure, and the covering metal active sites. Despite the improved acidity, direct introduction of Brønsted acid applied in catalysis show some disadvantages such as decrease of surface areas and pore volumes, metal active sites in MOF blocked by organic ligends with big shape, and reduced pore structure may impede the diffusion of reactants and products [32]. We were inspired by the precise hydrogen deoxygenation (PHDO) of biomass-derived oxygenates using acidic MOF and palladium-carbon hydrogenation catalysts under cascade reaction [33]. That one-pot PHDO reactions can be catalysed by tandem catalysts prepared by just mechanical mixing transition metal hydrogenation catalysts with MOF material. The synergistic reaction effect of 1+1 > 2 was achieved without affecting the MOF pore structure and reaction active sites. For solid Brønsted acids sites carrier materials, TiO2 has attracted much attention due to its stability, low-cost production, and minimum environmental impact. Solid Brønsted acids combined with TiO2 are an excellent and stable method to enhance the catalytic performance [34]. On the other hand, the rich surface hydroxyl group of TiO2 can also provide alkaline active sites for the reaction. At present, there are many reports on MIL-101(Cr)/TiO2 for photocatalysis. MIL-101(Cr)/TiO2 shows better advantages in both aspects, which can ensure the stability of MIL-101(Cr) as well as strong adsorption performance, and it also allows the high catalytic activity of TiO2 to be fully exposed to the catalyst surface [35]. But sulfonic acid carbonaceous supported porous TiO2 combining with MIL-101(Cr) for biomass conversion is soldem reported. This study used porous TiO2, sulfonic acid carbonaceous, and MIL-101(Cr) to construct a hybrid nanocomposite [36]. The introduction of porous TiO2 support for sulfonic acid carbonaceous not only reduces the influence on the open active sites of MIL-101(Cr), but also facilitates the esterification reaction due to the Lewis base brought by the hydroxyl group on the surface of TiO2. The open active sites of MIL-101(Cr) ensure an efficient hydrogen transfer reaction [37]. Sulfonic acid groups promote the dehydration of the esterification reaction and the lactonization reaction. The composite structure of TiO2-C-SO3H/MIL-101(Cr) guarantees the efficient cascade reaction. In addition, the prepared composites have controllable acidic sites and easily customized porous structures, which can be used as a valuable model to elucidate the relationship between structure and catalytic performance [38]. 2 Experimental procedure 2.1 Materials Chromic nitrate (Cr(NO3)3·9H2O) (A.R.), and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (A.R.) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., LTD. Anhydrous ethanol (A.R.) and isopropyl alcohol (A.R.) were purchased from Shanghai Lingfeng Chemical Reagent Co., LTD. Levulinic acid (LA) (A.R.) and furfural (FUR) (A.R.) were purchased from Shanghai McLean Biochemical Technology Co., LTD. Polyvinylimide (A.R.), acetic acid (A.R.), tetrabutyl titanate (A.R.) and sodium hydroxide (A.R.) are all obtained from Sinopharm Group. None of these reagents has been purified or pretreated. 2.2 Synthesis of porous TiO2 0.45 g polyvinylimide, 1 mL acetic acid and 1.7 g tetrabutyl titanate were ground in a mortar for 5 min to form a uniform composite material. Mesoporous TiO2 was obtained by heat treatment at 450 °C in Muffle furnace [39]. 2.3 Synthesis of TiO2-C-SO3H 2 g of the above prepared mesoporous TiO2 was mixed with 0.5 g FUR and 0.3 g hydroxyethyl sulfonic acid and added to 60 mL of distilled water, stirred for 1 h and the solution was transferred to 100 mL of polytetrafluoroethylene lined high-pressure reactor, heated to 180 °C, and hydrothermal reaction was conducted at this temperature for 4 h. The product was washed with distilled water for 3 times, and then washed with anhydrous ethanol for 3 times to complete the treatment after the reaction. The TiO2-C-SO3H product was obtained after the solid product was dried at 80 °C for 12 h, where C represents the hydrothermal formation of carbonaceous, -SO3H represents the sulfonic acid group on the carbonaceous. The obtained sample was denoted as TS. 2.4 Synthesis of TiO2-C-SO3H/MIL-101(Cr) composites 2 mmol Cr(NO3)3 9H2O, 2 mmol 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC), 5 mmol NaOH, the above TS (300 mg, 400 mg, 500 mg) were weighed, and added into the beaker with 30 mL of deionized water. After stirring for 30 minutes, the mixture was transfered into a 80 mL teflon-lined autoclave reactor and heated at 220°C for 12 h. After centrifugation at the end of the reaction, the solid product was washed with deionized water, ethanol and N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF), and then dried in a vacuum drying oven at 80°C. The obtained products were denoted as TSM-0.3, TSM-0.4 and TMS-0.5 according to the added amount of TS (300 mg, 400 mg, 500 mg). Other synthesis processes of comparative samples are shown in Notes S1-S4. 2.5 Characterization The X-ray diffraction was employed to characterize the crystal structure using Cu Kα radiation (wide Angle) in the range of 10∼80° at a scanning speed of 10°·min−1(Rigaku SmartLab SE, Japan). The morphology of TSM composites were characterized by field emission scanning electron microscopy (Zeiss Gemini 300, Germany). The elemental composition of the samples were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha). The porous structure of samples was characterized by Micromeritics APSP 2460. The samples were tested by nitrogen adsorption and desorption program mode after degassing for 48 h at 200°C, and the obtained isothermal curves were employed to calculate the specific surface areas and pore volumes of the materials. The pore size distributions were calculated using adsorption branch of curves. The functional groups of the samples were measured by the Nicolet iS50 Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrometer (Thermo Fisher, USA). The stability of samples was tested by TG 209F3 thermogravimetric (TG) analyzer under nitrogen atmosphere. The heating rate was 10 °C·min−1, and the thermogravimetric curves were obtained. The procedure of pyridine adsorption FT-IR characization is shown in Note S5. 2.6 The catalytic behaviour and procedure Esterification of levulinic acid with alcohol. 4 mmol of LA was dissolved into 20 mL ethanol [40], and higher ethanol content was conducive to the forward movement of esterification reaction and increased mass transfer power. The reaction was carried out in a 50 mL microreactor of Quick-opening miniature reactor (Shanghai Yanzheng Experimental Instrument Co., LTD) with 80 mg of catalyst in different loads and magnetically stirred at 80∼120 °C (1000 rpm · min−1). Direct synthesis of GVL from LA or FUR. The one-pot reaction was performed using the following procedure: 4 mmol of LA (or FUR), 20 mL of alcohols in 50 mL microreactor of Quick-opening miniature reactor (Shanghai Yanzheng Experimental Instrument Co., LTD) with 80 mg of catalyst in different loads and magnetically stirred at 160 °C (1000 rpm · min−1). The react system was took sample at regular intervals of one hour and the sample was determined by a gas chromatograph (Shanghai Eyou Electronic Technology GC-7860 plus) on 30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.4 µm SE-54 (cross-linked) column with a hydrogen flame detector (FID) with N2 as the carrier gas. The column temperature was 100°C and the detector temperature was 260°C. Nuclear magnetic resonance spectrometer (AVANCE III 500M NMR type of Bruck Company, Switzerland) was also used for qualitative and quantitative analysis of the product, the esterification rate and selectivity were calculated. Density functional theory (DFT) methods were descreibed in Note S.6. Conversion(%) = [(initial moles of LA-final moles of LA)/initial moles of LA] × 100% Yieldi(%)= [(moles of producti formed)/initial moles of LA] × 100% Conversion(%) = [(initial moles of FUR-final moles of FUR)/initial moles of FUR] × 100% Yieldi(%)= [(moles of producti formed)/initial moles of FUR] × 100% 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizations of TSM samples The diffraction peaks of MIL-101(Cr) at 2θ angles of 8.69° and 17.06° are illustrated in Figs. 1 (a) and S1. The samples exhibit discernible crystallinity, with no characteristic peaks associated with impurities observed, suggesting a high purity of the MOF sample [41]. The TSM samples display five distinct crystal peaks at 2θ angles ranging from 25.2 to 55.2°, corresponding to the 101, 004, 200, 105, and 211 reflections for the anatase phase (JCPDS no. 21-1272) [42].The structural characteristic peaks of MIL-101(Cr) in the samples are prominently displayed, indicating that the TSM samples possess the dual structural characteristics of TiO2 (Fig. S2) and MIL-101(Cr). To further investigate the carbon materials, Raman patterns were also analyzed (Fig. 1(c)), revealing two wide overlapping bands at approximately 1361 cm−1 (D band) and 1650 cm−1 (G band). The D-band signifies the expansion vibration of the carbon sp2 bond within the hexagonal lattice, while the G-band represents the vibration of carbon atoms with suspended bonds in the amorphous carbon network. The ID/IG ratio can measure graphitization, with low values indicating amorphous carbon [43]. FT-IR spectra (Fig. 1(b)) shows the weak peak observed at 1600 cm−1 can be attributed to the C=C bond within the benzene ring, while the absorption peaks at 1631 and 1379 cm−1 belong to asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of -COO groups. And the peak locked at 587 cm−1 belongs to the Cr-O. For TS, the peak at 516 cm−1 can be ascribed to O-Ti-O stretching, the characteristic peaks at 1124 and 1061 cm−1 can be attributed to the stretching vibrations of the S=O double bond and S-O single bond. These IR spectra of the samples demonstrated that the bands of TS and MIL- 101(Cr) shifted owing to the interaction between 101(Cr) and TS [35,44,45]. The thermal properties of MOF and TSM composites were analyzed (Fig. 1(d)), with MIL-101(Cr) showing three mass loss steps in TG curves. The first step involved the loss of water molecules, with MIL-101(Cr) and TSM-0.4 losing 12.15% and 22.74% of their weight, respectively. The second step saw mass changes of 45.42% and 22.91%, likely due to functional group molecule decomposition. Weight loss at 400∼550 °C is 4.65% and 3.46%, respectively, due to combustion of organic ash. The composite has lower heat loss than pure MIL-101(Cr), but its thermal stability is not significantly improved due to its low organic content. Fig. 2 (a) and (b) display the absorption and desorption isotherms as well as the pore size distributions of all samples. It is evident that all samples exhibit a type IV isotherm in accordance with the BDDT classification rule. The sample labeled TS demonstrates a type H2 hysteresis loop indicative of an "ink bottle" mesopore system (Fig. 2(a)), contrasting with the H1 type observed in pure TiO2 (Fig. S3). This discrepancy is attributed to the incorporation of nano C-SO3H carbonaceous material, which impacts the ordered mesoporous pore structure of TiO2. During hydrothermal treatment, nano C-SO3H carbonaceous material was synthesized within the mesopores of TiO2, leading to a transformation of the original cylindrical mesoporous structure into a "ink bottle" mesopore configuration [46]. The MIL-101(Cr) material exhibited a typical type IV isotherm with a H4 hysteresis loop. The significant N2 adsorption capacity at low pressures (P/P0 = 0∼0.2) suggests the presence of numerous micropores, while the hysteresis loop indicates the existence of mesoporous structures. The specific surface area of TS is measured at 106.2 m2·g−1, while that of MIL-101(Cr) is notably higher at 1887.2 m2·g−1. The specific surface areas of the TSM composites exhibit an increase from 745.9 to 966.7 m2·g−1 with the inclusion of MIL-101(Cr), as shown in Table 1 . The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of TSM samples demonstrate a composite of MIL-101(Cr) and TS. The pore size distributions of TSM samples play a crucial role in the formation of various porous structures. This structure is very beneficial to promote the mass transfer of reactants within the catalyst and improve the contact with the catalytic active sites [47,48]. The XPS analysis confirmed the presence of C, O, N, S, Ti, and Cr elements in the composites, as shown in Fig. 3 (a). The binding energies of the C1s peaks at 284.8 eV and 286.1 eV correspond to C-C and C-O bonds, respectively (Fig. 3(b)). Upon interaction with MIL-101(Cr), the binding energy of 288.8 eV for C=O became more pronounced, indicating the presence of the organic ligand from MIL-101(Cr) [49]. The binding energies of Cr 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 in MIL-101(Cr) were measured at 577.1 eV and 586.8 eV, respectively, while in the TSM composites, these values shifted to 577.8 eV and 587.4 eV, as illustrated in Fig. 3(c). It meant that the zirconium atoms in TSM had the higher positive charge and thus the stronger Lewis acidity [50]. The O 1s spectrum of TS exhibits a prominent peak at 530 eV, corresponding to lattice oxygen in TiO2, with additional peaks at 531.7 eV and 533.5 eV attributed to the S-O bond and non-lattice oxygen bridging the hydroxyl group. In the O 1s spectrum of the TSM composite, peaks at binding energies of 530.4 eV, 532.1 eV, and 533.5 eV were identified as C-O, M-O, and O-H, respectively (see Fig. 3(d)). The peaks observed at 159.6 eV and 161.9 eV in the TS sample are attributed to the S 2p3/2 and S 2p1/2 orbitals, respectively, while the peaks at 168.6 eV are attributed to S4+ of the sulfonic acid group (see Fig. 3(e)). In the TSM sample, the peaks corresponding to S 2p3/2 and S 2p1/2 exhibited a shift towards lower energy levels, measuring 159.1 eV and 160.2 eV, respectively. This shift suggests a significant increase in electron density on the sulfur atom. Furthermore, the bond energies at 464.4 eV and 458.9 eV are associated with Ti 2p1/2 and Ti 2p3/2, respectively, indicating the presence of TiO2 in the composite material (see Fig. 3(f)). In comparison to pure TiO2, the Ti 2p peak in TS and TSM exhibits a positive shift of 0.8 eV, indicating a decrease in electron density from titanium in the composite (see Fig. S4) [51]. Notably, the Cr 2p3/2, and 2p1/2 XPS peaks of TSM shifted towards higher binding energies compared to MIL-101(Cr), suggesting a strong electronic interaction between TS and MIL-101(Cr). The above results successfully indicate the formation process of TS with MIL-101(Cr) and the possible existence of strong electronic interaction, which is conducive to enhancing charge flow and the acidity of the catalytic active sites [52]. Fig. 4 (a) and (b) show SEM images of MIL-101(Cr), which appear nearly spherical with some polydispersity. And the structure of TS is also similar to microspheres (Fig. S5). Fig. 4 (c) shows similar structures to the MIL-101(Cr) and TS microspheres, with a closer look in Fig. 4 (d) confirming the state of a dispersed uniform composite. Furthermore, the absence of discernible MIL-101(Cr) particles on the surface indicates that the MOF particles are integrated within the composite matrix. Elemental mapping patterns of carbon, oxygen, titanium, nitrogen, and sulfur in the TSM composite further confirm the uniform distribution of MIL-101(Cr) particles throughout the composite (Fig. 4(e)-(i)). 3.2 Performance of TSM as catalyst for LA esterification The study aimed to assess the catalytic efficiency of various catalysts, including TS, MIL-101(Cr), TSM-0.3, TSM-0.4, and TSM-0.5, in the liquid-phase esterification of LA with ethanol (EtOH). The results, depicted in Fig. 5 (a), indicated that after a reaction time of 6 hours at 100 °C, the yields of ethyl laurate (EL) were 31.1%, 66.0%, 82.3%, 85.6%, and 79.4% for the respective catalysts. It was observed that while titanium dioxide (TiO2) can activate ethanol, its effectiveness is limited at low temperatures, resulting in esterification conversion rates of less than 10% when used as a sole catalyst (Table S1 entries 2). However, the presence of the -SO3H group in TS led to a significant enhancement in catalytic conversion, with a yield of 31.1% (Table S1 entries 3). Nevertheless, the catalytic efficiency of the reaction is suboptimal, potentially due to the limited specific surface area and pore capacity of TS, consequently hindering the enhancement of the conversion rate. Despite the absence of -SO3H groups in the MIL-101(Cr) structure, the unsaturated Cr coordination as potent Lewis acid active sites, coupled with the high specific surface area of the MOF material, enables effective activation of the carbonyl group on the LA, leading to heightened catalytic esterification activity of MOF materials (Table S1 entries 6). The catalytic yields of the composite catalysts of TSM demonstrate significantly higher activities compared to TS and MIL-101(Cr). Specifically, TSM-0.4 exhibits the highest catalytic activity. Subsequent reaction optimization was conducted to assess the impact of temperature and reaction time. At 80 °C, the conversion of LA to EL was relatively slower for TSM-0.4, resulting in a yield of 67.6% after 6 hours. However, when the reaction temperature was increased to 120 °C, LA was nearly completely converted to EL within the same 6-hour timeframe, yielding 99.0% (Fig. 5(b)). Elevating the reaction temperature and extending the reaction duration has the potential to enhance the yield of EL. In addition to catalytic activity, the recyclability and stability of catalysts are essential factors to consider for practical applications. The catalyst utilized was isolated through centrifugation and subjected to multiple washes with anhydrous ethanol. The yield of EL after 5 cycles by TSM-0.4 is depicted in Fig. 5(c), demonstrating an esterification rate of 89.6% after recycling. These findings indicate that the composite exhibits outstanding stability and reproducibility. The physical mixing of TS and MIL-101(Cr) as a catalyst did not result in an enhanced conversion rate of the catalytic reaction, with rates even lower than those observed with MOF alone (Table S1 entries 5 and 7). This indicates the necessity of concentrating different reaction sites within close proximity to achieve synergistic effects. Instead of TiO2, sulfonic acid groups and MOF each promote a simple addition of esterification. Furthermore, the presence of sulfonic acid groups significantly impacts the conversion rate (Table S1 entry 8). While sulfonic acid groups can enhance the catalytic activity of MIL-101(Cr), their effectiveness is limited in the absence of synergistic interactions with TiO2 (Table S1 entry 9). The impact of the porous structure of TiO2 on reaction conversion efficiency is evident. Comparative analysis reveals that the catalyst synthesized using porous TiO2 as the substrate exhibits higher reaction activity than that synthesized with conventional TiO2 (Table S2). The experimental results indicate that the improved catalytic activity is due to the presence of Lewis acid sites (unsaturated Cr), Brønsted acid sites (sulfonic acid group), and porous TiO2 (surface hydroxyl group as Lewis base), creating a synergistic effect in esterification. Additionally, the esterification conversion rate of alcohols varies with their structure, decreasing as the carbon chain length increases (Fig. 5(d)). Steric hindrance causes secondary alcohols to have lower esterification conversion rates than primary alcohols. Fig. 5(d) illustrates this: primary alcohols (methanol, ethanol, n-propanol, n-butanol) yield low amounts of alcohol GVL (0-4.3%) and mainly produce levulinate (LAE). In contrast, secondary alcohols (isopropanol, isobutanol) yield higher GVL (12.8% and 10.3%), indicating that primary alcohols favor the acetal reaction. Secondary alcohols are beneficial to MPV reaction. Subsequently, the yield of GVL decreased slightly with the increase of secondary alcohol carbon number. The reaction mechanism of the proposed TSM catalyst in the esterification of levulinic acid and ethanol is illustrated in Fig. 6 . Initially, LA coordinates with the unsaturated Cr coordination site of MIL-101(Cr), with the carbonyl group on the carboxylic acid exhibiting enhanced coordination to the chromium site. Our calculations indicate that this coordination results in a longer bond length (increasing from 1.21 Å to 1.23 Å) and the adsorption process was more spontaneous due to the adsorption energy is -106.8 kJ/mol, thereby facilitating nucleophilic attack by the alcohol molecule (Fig. S6). However, according to the calculated results, an unsaturated coordination activity is difficult to activate alcohols. This also proves that it is very difficult for MOFs to activate alcohols by Lewis acid. Previous research [53] indicates that carboxylic acid binds more favorably than carbonyl groups to Lewis acidic sites. Consequently, in MIL-101(Cr), the unsaturated metal sites preferentially activate the carbonyl group of carboxylic acids. On TiO2 surfaces, hydroxyl groups act as Lewis bases to activate alcohols. Specifically, TiO2 activates ethanol and isopropyl alcohol to form ethoxy and isopropoxy nucleophiles, respectively. But ethanol is easier to activate because the adsorption energy is much more than isopropyl alcohol (-327.28 kJ/mol vs -12.9 kJ/mol)(Fig. S7). This is in agreement with the actual value of esterification experiment. Additionally, the -SO3H group present on TSM acts as a Brønsted acid, facilitating the departure of the -OH leaving group in the -COOH group of levulinic acid to form levulinate. The presence of a benzene ring in the MIL-101(Cr) structure results in a decrease in the hydrophilicity of TSM and enhances its dehydration activity [54]. TSM has weak Lewis acid sites and strong Brønsted acid sites with high total acidity, whereas MIL-101(Cr) has strong Lewis acid sites and lower total acidity (Fig. 7 and Table 2 ). The catalytic active sites work synergistically due to the interface effect between components, not just physical blending. 3.3 Performance of TSM catalyzing LA direct synthesis of GVL We investigated the direct conversion of LA to GVL via MPV reaction using a mix of ethanol and isopropyl alcohol. Existing methods often require levulinate due to low catalyst activity with LA. Our one-step method for converting LA to GVL marks a significant process improvement. To further clarify the influence of catalyst acidity on its activity and selectivity, the conversion and selectivity of GVL from LA was investigated. This direct synthesis process is coupled to esterification, MPV reduction, and lactonization in cascade reactions (Fig. 8 ). Fig. 9 (a) shows that TSM-0.3, TSM-0.4, and TSM-0.5 catalysts maintain a high conversion rate (>99%). However, varying the MOF ratio affects product selectivity. Increasing the sulfonic acid group (Brønsted acid site) boosts GVL selectivity, but reducing the MOF component lowers Lewis acid content, impacting the MPV reduction process and decreasing selectivity for 4-HAE and GVL. TSM-0.4 achieves an optimal Lewis to Brønsted acid ratio, ensuring high conversion and GVL selectivity. The conversion and selectivity of the three important components of TSM catalyst cannot be achieved alone or in combination (Fig. S8). It is of concern that the use of ethanol mixed with isopropyl alcohol can further affect the selectivity of GVL. The yield of GVL increased from 84.1% to 94.5% with the increase of molar ratio of ethanol in mixed alcohols (0∼0.15). When the proportion of ethanol increases further, the selectivity decreases, which may be because too much ethanol will occupy the catalytic active sites and affect the reduction of isopropyl alcohol (Fig. 9(b)) [55]. Esterification is crucial for the translation system's efficiency. Comparative experiments showed that ethyl 4-hydroxyvalerate converts to GVL more effectively than 4-hydroxyvaleric acid (Fig. S9). This is because the carbonyl group in ethyl 4-hydroxyvalerate is less acidic and more easily protonated by Brønsted acid, facilitating the lactonification reaction (Fig. 10 ). This also explains why adding more esterified ethanol to the reaction can improve the conversion efficiency of GVL while improving the esterification efficiency. When mixed alcohols are used, the content of LAE reaches its highest value at 2 h and then slowly decreases, which is because the esterification reaction has been completed (Fig. 9(c)). In the reaction system using isopropyl alcohol alone, it takes 3 h for the LAE content to reach its maximum, because the esterification efficiency of isopropyl alcohol is lower than that of ethanol (Fig. 9(d)). To further demonstrate the synergistic effect of Lewis and Brønsted acids in catalysis, the catalyst was treated with ammonia water to shield the proton acid (Note S7). This treatment reduced the catalyst's conversion rate but significantly altered its selectivity (Fig. 9(e)). Specifically, TSM-0.4′s selectivity for GVL decreased, while its selectivity for intermediate 4-HAE increased, indicating that Brønsted acid's active site is crucial for lactonic esterification. MPV reduction was also investigated separately, It is worth noting that the MPV-reducing activity of TS was not higher than that of MIL-101(Cr) (Fig. S10). So many reports about MPV reduction reaction indicate that the reaction is coordinated by Lewis acid-base active sites [56,57]. The Ti-OH on the surface of TiO2 belongs to Lewis base [58], which doesn't play the role of activating isopropyl alcohol. Theoretically, the Lewis acid sites activated the carbonyl groups of LAE, while the base sites were beneficial for the dissociation of hydroxyl groups in isopropyl alcohol to form the active H adatom [59]. This may be due to the fact that the Lewis acid and base sites are too far apart from each other, not atomic adjacent sites, making it difficult to form the six-membered ring structure required for MPV reduction. Through DFT calculation, we explored whether a single Lewis acid active site played a role in the MPV reduction process or whether two Lewis active sites acted simultaneously. The adsorption energy of ethyl levulinate and isopropyl alcohol adsorbed on two adjacent Cr atoms is obviously higher than that on the same Cr atom. This suggests that ethyl levulinate and isopropyl alcohol are more spontaneously activated by adjacent Cr atoms in the Cr-O atomic cluster of MIL-101 (Cr)(Fig. 11 and Fig. S11). This is also more consistent with the unsaturated coordination structure of MIL-101 [40]. In addition, it is difficult to form two unsaturated complexes at a single Cr site on MOF unit. It is worth noting that the activity of TSM after ammonia treatment to esterification and reduction is still relatively high, significantly higher than that of MIL-101 (Cr). This shows that the rearrangement of electrons at the interface of the composite catalyst leads to the enhancement of the acidity of Lewis acid, which is consistent with the results of XPS characterization. In addition, -C-SO3H alone has a limited catalytic effect, which may be caused by the low specific surface area and has little activity for MPV reduction due to the absence of Lewis acid sites. The activity of physical mixed catalysts is also difficult to match that of TSM composite catalysts (Fig. S12). This also proves that there is an important synergistic enhancement between the components of the composite catalyst [60,61]. The reuse performance of the TSM catalyst was also studied, and the conversion rate decreased slightly after the catalyst was reused for 5 times, while the GVL yield also decreased slightly (Fig. 9(f)). The observed phenomenon may be attributed to the loss of sulfonic acid groups. Therefore, ensuring that the protic acid group is more securely anchored without compromising the pore structure of the catalyst represents a critical scientific challenge that warrants further investigation. Utilizing ML and EL as substrates has demonstrated the potential to achieve yields exceeding 95% within a 6-hour timeframe, underscoring the importance of efficient esterification in the synthesis of GVL (Fig. S13). In contrast, the use of conventional TiO2 results in markedly lower conversion rates and GVL yields, even when the reaction time is extended to 12 hours (Fig. S14) [62]. This demonstrates the critical role of the double-porous structure in both esterification and subsequent reduction and lactonification processes. The relevant GC-MS data are shown in Table S3. 3.4 Performance of TSM catalyzing FUR direct synthesis of GVL Following our conclusion, we extended the reaction process using FUR to synthesize GVL (Fig. 12 ). In this process, Lewis acid primarily drives the MPV reaction, while Brønsted acid aids in esterification and promotes the ring-opening reaction. Unlike using LA as raw material, the final GVL yield increases with higher Brønsted acid content. Specifically, TSM-0.5 yields 3.9% and 7.3% more GVL than TSM-0.4 and TSM-0.3, respectively (Fig. S16 (a)). TSM-0.3 yields more FA likely due to its low Brønsted acid content, which slows FE formation from FA. To study GVL yield, mixed alcohols were used. Ethanol, with less steric hindrance than isopropyl alcohol, speeds up the reaction and boosts GVL yield when added in small amounts. However, excessive ethanol can reduce GVL yield by occupying active sites and hindering the MPV reaction (Fig. S16 (b)). Initially, the intermediate content rose but later declined as GVL yield increased (Fig. S16 (c)). Notably, GVL content grew slowly in the first 4 hours and then accelerated. This could be due to FUR occupying the catalytic sites early on; as FUR concentration drops, intermediates FA, FE, and LAE take over these sites to produce GVL. This suggests that both the conversion from FUR to LAE and from LAE to GVL use the same catalytic sites. Using isopropyl alcohol alone significantly reduced the GVL yield to 74.5% and extended the time to reach peak intermediate content to 8 hours (Fig. S16 (d)). Post-ammonia treatment, the conversion selectivity of TSM to FUR changed notably due to the shielding of Brønsted acid (Fig. S16 (e)). This led to a significant increase in FE yield, while LAE and GVL yields dropped, as LAE formation from FE relies on Brønsted acid sites. The catalyst effectively recycles through five cycles without significant change (Fig. S16 (f)). The 100mg catalyst, which was reused 5 times, was washed 3 times with 20mL ethanol and dried. The crystal structure, pore structure, and pore size distribution are almost unchanged (Fig. S17). The porous structure is crucial for reaction conversion and selectivity; using ordinary TiO2 instead of porous TiO2 greatly reduces conversion and GVL yield (Fig. S15) [63,64]. Compared with the catalysts mentioned in the literature, these catalysts also have advantages in the synthesis of GVL (Table S4). 3.5 Catalytic ability of TSM for other biomass products The TSM catalytic system effectively synthesizes various biomass products, achieving up to 95% yield for industrial ester plasticizers like DOP, DOS, DOA, and TOTM (Table S5, Entries 1-4) [65]. It handles substrates ranging from dicarboxylic to tricarboxylic acids and from aromatic to alkyl carboxylic acids of different chain lengths. This catalytic system efficiently facilitates polyol esterification, with triester yields increasing alongside carboxylic acid acidity (Entries 9-12). It also effectively catalyzes long-chain carboxylic acids like oleic acid, showing higher efficiency with short-chain alcohols (Entries 5-8) [66-67]. 4 Conclsuion In summary, the successful synthesis and utilization of TiO2-C-SO3H/MIL-101(Cr) composites as catalysts for the esterification of levulinic acid and the direct synthesis of GVL from levulinic acid and FUR resulted in ethyl levulinate yields of 100% at 120 °C for 6 hours and GVL yields of up to 94.5% at 160 °C for 9 hours. Even when FUR was used as a feedstock, the GVL yield in the cascade reaction remained high at 89.5% at 160 °C for 16 hours. This remarkable catalytic performance can be attributed to the synergistic effects of various factors. a) Experiments and DFT results show that the unsaturated coordination metal in MOF acts as a Lewis acid to activate the carbonyl group, while the surface hydroxyl group of TiO2 acts as a Lewis base to activate the alcohol hydroxyl group. Sulfonic acid groups aid in the departure of the -OH leaving group in levulinic acid, ensuring efficient esterification. b) The presence of the hydroxyl group on the surface of TiO2 as a Lewis base did not result in an increase in MPV reactivity, as determined by the dual Cr sites located adjacent to each other in the SBU of MIL-101(Cr). c) Utilizing an appropriate proportion of mixed alcohols not only enhances the efficiency of the esterification reaction, but also improves the efficiency of MPV reduction. d) The dual-porous structure of porous TiO2 and MOF facilitates effective mass transfer of reactants and intermediates, ultimately leading to enhanced synergistic effects that promote more efficient conversion of the reaction. Overall, the combination of Lewis acid/base and Brønsted acid sites, and porous structure promote cascade reactions with high catalytic activity retention and recyclability. This study suggests a new approach using MOF/Metallic oxides composites as catalysts for biomass conversion to biofuels and chemicals, with potential for various applications. In order to further high reactivity, our future research will focus on accurately constructing the defects of MOF materials, increasing the number and exposure of unsaturated coordination sites, and shortening the distance of Lewis acid and base active sites. coredata.dc:description: Development of heterogeneous catalysts with both Brønsted and Lewis acid properties has proved to be promising and useful because they offer an efficient way to cascade reactions. In this study, we present the synthesis pathway and efficacy evaluation of new composites which combined by sulfonic acid functional group modified TiO2 and MIL-101, analyzing their structure-performance correlation as heterogeneous catalysts in cascade reactions involving esterification, hydrogen transfer, and lactonization. These composites possess an open porous structure (MOF and porous TiO2), as well as active sites including Lewis acid (unsaturated coordination metal), Lewis base (Ti-OH), and Brønsted acid (-SO3H). The role of these active sites and the synergies between them were investigated through the esterification of levulinic acid and the direct synthesis of γ-valerolactone from levulinic acid and furfural under cascade reactions. The composites exhibit a 100% ethyl levulinate (EL) yield at 120°C for 6 hours, with γ-valerolactone yields reaching up to 94.5% (160 °C, 9 h) and 89.5% (160 °C, 16 h) from levulinic acid and furfural, respectively. This synergistic effect of Lewis acid/base and Brønsted acid ensures efficient esterification. The presence of a sulfonic acid group promotes the lactonization reaction, while the Meerwein-Ponndorf-Verley reduction is facilitated by the dual Cr sites located adjacent to each other in the secondary building unit of MIL-101(Cr). Moreover, the double-porous structure of porous TiO2 and MIL-101(Cr) effectively guarantees the efficient mass transfer of reactants and intermediates, leading to enhanced synergistic effects that promote more efficient reaction conversion.
